items.content_html:
Summary

Set Firefox 92 as stable

Test results and supporting details

https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/92.0/releasenotes/
items.title: Set Firefox 92 as stable

items.content_html: Cherry-picked from #12300. This PR updates the notes regarding the default value of rtcpMuxPolicy for Chrome when creating a new instance and indicates what the new default value is. Currently, the notes don't mention what the new default value is, which is slightly unhelpful. (There's only two values available, but this note update removes the need to scroll up on the page and find that out.)
items.title: Update notes regarding default value of an RTCPeerConnection option

items.content_html:
This PR corrects the data throughout the RTCPeerConnection API, which was a big mess (most likely due to copy-paste error). The fixes include the following:

  • Add data regarding the prefixed constructor This one was done in #12196 already, though the non-prefixed version number was a little off based on my testing, so this is a quick correction.
  • Updates the notes regarding the default rtcpMuxPolicy value in Chrome when constructing a new instance. The notes didn't mention what the new default value is, which is slightly unhelpful. (There's only two values available, but the note update removes the need to scroll up on the page and find that out.) Cherry-picked in #12301.
  • Remove the meaningless "Promise-based version" notes. These notes don't seem helpful at all, and as they were copied and pasted all across the Opera data, actually caused some major data discrepancies. (Particularly, claiming support for features in Opera that weren't supported, wrong version numbers...) Fixes #11158.
  • Corrects the Samsung Internet and Opera/Opera Android data. In the case of Samsung Internet, it appears to have been set to 6.0 most everywhere after a mirroring from the old, incorrect wiki data (#1606), and Opera's data initially came from the wiki tables (#1070). When the Chrome data was corrected, however (see #3287), only the Chrome, Chrome Android, and WebView data was adjusted, leaving these other browsers untouched.
  • Finally, mirrors the Chrome data to both Chrome Android and WebView. Both had been left as true for many of the features, however since we have ranged values, we're able to replace the true with â‰¤37 for WebView, and mirror Chrome straight to Chrome Android since we know Chrome Android has supported this API back then.

There's a lot of changes made in this PR, so I would love to get it reviewed and merged ASAP!
items.title: Correct data for the RTCPeerConnection API

items.content_html:
This PR updates and corrects the real values for Chromium (Chrome, Opera, Samsung Internet, WebView Android) for the RTCDataChannel API, based upon both commit history and results from the mdn-bcd-collector project (v3.2.12).

Commit-based data:
https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/ce4f330106a77d5f5c2a5b4d7b7abbb1bf7a299e (Chrome 24 (mirrored from RTCPeerConnection.createDataChannel): RTCDataChannel, label, reliable, readyState, bufferedAmount, binaryType, send, close, onopen, onerror, onclose, onmessage, open_event, error_event, close_event, message_event)
https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/138b48a5d343fa8688ecf5ee120edd2e8a8841b9 (Chrome 30 (based upon feature freeze date of Jul 26, 2013): ordered, maxRetransmits, protocol, negotiated, id)
All other changes: https://mdn-bcd-collector.appspot.com/tests/api/RTCDataChannel
items.title: Update Chromium versions for RTCDataChannel API

items.content_html: This PR removes the RTCIceCandidateInit dictionary from BCD and folds its members into the RTCIceCandidate constructor where it is primarily used.
items.title: Delete RTCIceCandidateInit dictionary from BCD

items.content_html:
This PR adds real values for Chromium (Chrome, Opera, Samsung Internet, WebView Android) for the request member of the FetchEvent API, based upon commit history and date.

Commit: https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/451a831fc3cb3c0b845298abbdde172219444d9f
items.title: Add Chromium versions for api.FetchEvent.request

items.content_html:
The HTML spec added a global event handler onsecuritypolicyviolation in whatwg/html#2651.

  • Firefox adding in FF93 : https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1727302
  • Webkit adding/added in https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=229381
  • Chromium not yet added https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1242893

I need help to work out whether this is in Safari yet. I also updated the SecurityPolicyViolationEvent to indicate it is not experimental - based on broad rollout.

A few more questions I'd like to address in a separate PR

  1. Spec indicates handler is on Window and Document too https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#event-handlers-on-elements,-document-objects,-and-window-objects
  • Testing shows that onsecuritypolicyviolation is present on Chrome in Window and Document, but not in elements.
  • Notes indicate it is present Document in Safari.
  • FF92 does not have the onsecuritypolicyviolation at all but you can add a listener for securitypolicyviolation

What this means is that there is already a Document.onsecuritypolicyviolation supported in Chrome/Safari and Window.onsecuritypolicyviolation in Chrome only. These predate the global version and can only be used on those objects.
Do I need to add BCD entries for those or is there some better way to address this?

  1. The spec says securitypolicyviolation is fired off elements, and indeed on all versions you can add a listener for the event in document or window and catch it. But the event is not in BCD.
    • Would I be right in adding this as a feature securitypolicyviolation_event to HTMLElement?
    • Could I use the same versions as for the corresponding event object SecurityPolicyViolationEvent?
items.title: onsecuritypolicyviolation global event handler and friends

items.content_html:
This PR adds real values for Safari (Desktop and iOS/iPadOS) for the TextMetrics API, based upon results from the mdn-bcd-collector project (v3.2.12).

Tests Used: https://mdn-bcd-collector.appspot.com/tests/api/TextMetrics
items.title: Add Safari versions for TextMetrics API

items.content_html: This PR's goal is to delete the PaymentDetailsUpdate dictionary from BCD. First, this copies the Firefox flag, note and version data from PaymentDetailsUpdate to PaymentRequest and PaymentRequestUpdateEvent, which fixes consistency issues. Afterwards, the entries within the dictionary are copied as subfeatures to both PaymentRequest.show and PaymentRequestUpdateEvent.updateWith, the two methods that use this dictionary. Finally, the dictionary is deleted.
items.title: Update flag data for PaymentRequest[UpdateEvent]; delete PaymentDetailsUpdate dictionary

items.content_html:
Summary

Firefox 93 supports datetime-local, updates version to reflect this.

Test results and supporting details

Downloaded nightly build, checked if it worked on https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/input/datetime-local

See https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1283388

Related issues

Fixes #12248
items.title: Firefox 93 supports datetime-local

items.content_html:
Summary

According to #11989, Opera has version 77 compatibility for api.Navigator.share.

In this PR, compatibility for the version has been included.

Related issues

Fixes #11989.
items.title: Include api.Share compatibility on Opera 77

items.content_html:
Navigator.share() was marked false for FireFox desktop. However testing shows that it does work for desktop Windows (at least). I think it was added in FF71 in this bug behind the preference dom.webshare.enabled.
Note that FF android is not blocked by this preference.

I also did some testing and verified that Navigator.share() and Navigator.canShare() work on Windows Opera and Edge, and also Opera Android. I have guessed the versions for desktop match Chrome (but without the partial implementation warning due, I think, to MacOS issues).

Upshot, those changes might perhaps revert to true if you think this is not a safe assumption.

FYI these methods are protected by web-share permission. I have not added subfeatures for that, because I don't know if it is a compatibility issue (at all).
items.title: FF supports navigator.share behind pref
